The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date(s): April 20, 2016 and February 11, 2016
§ 3.75(c)(1) - Housing facilities, general.

Surfaces. General requirements. The surfaces of housing facilities — including perches, shelves,
swings, boxes, houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures or objects within the facility ~ must be
constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and sanitized, or
removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Furniture-type fixtures or objects must be sturdily constructed and
must be strong enough to provide for the safe activity and welfare of nonhuman primates. Floors may be
made of dirt, absorbent bedding, sand, gravel, grass, or other similar material that can be readily cleaned, or
can be removed or replaced whenever cleaning does not eliminate odors, diseases, pests, insects, or vermin.
Any surfaces that come in contact with nonhuman primates.

Date(s): April 20, 2016, February 11, 2016, November 12, 2015, August 18, 2015, March 25, 2015 and
November 12, 2014

§ 3.125(a) - Facilities, general.
Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as

appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound
and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

Date(s): April 20, 2016, February 11, 2016 and November 12, 2015
§ 3.125(d) - Facilities, general.

Waste disposal. Provision shall be made for the removal and disposal of animal and food wastes,
bedding, dead animals, trash and debris. Disposal facilities shall be so provided and operated as to minimize
vermin infestation, odors, and disease hazards. The disposal facilities and any disposal of animal and food
wastes, bedding, dead animals, trash, and debris shall comply with applicable Federal, State, and local laws
and regulations relating to pollution control or the protection of the environment.

Ce

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer



## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_2
Date(s): November 12, 2015, August 18, 2015, March 25, 2015 and November 12, 2014

§ 3.75(c)(3) - Housing facilities, general.

Surfaces. Cleaning. Hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot-
cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance with § 3.84 of this subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or
disease hazards. If the species scent mark, the surfaces must be sanitized or replaced at regular intervals as
determined by the attending veterinarian in accordance with generally accepted professional and husbandry
practices. Floors made of dirt, absorbent bedding, sand, gravel, grass, or other similar material, and planted
enclosures must be raked or spot-cleaned with sufficient frequency to ensure all animals the freedom to
avoid contact with excreta. Contaminated material must be removed or replaced whenever raking and spot
cleaning does not eliminate odors, diseases, insects, pests, or vermin infestation. All other surfaces of
housing facilities must be cleaned and sanitized when necessary to satisfy generally accepted husbandry
standards and practices. Sanitization may be done by any of the methods provided in § 3.84(b)(3) of this
subpart for primary enclosures.

Date(s): March 25, 2015
§ 2.40(b)(3) — Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that
include: Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That
daily observation of animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and
Provided, further, That a mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending
veterinarian

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:
Attps://acissearch. aphis.usda.gowLP ASearch/,

aces/ Warning js

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date(s): July 14, 2016 and September 15, 2015
§ 2.33(b)(2) — Attending Veterinarian and Adequate Veterinary Care.

Each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include
the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

https://acissearch.aphis. usda.gow/LPASearch/faces/Warning.js,

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date(s): July 5, 2016

§ 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,
except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section,
must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a
license shall apply on a form which will be furnished by the AC Regional Director in the State in which that
person operates or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at
all times, and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records may be
inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional
Director.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:
hitps://acissearch.aphis.usda.gowLPASearch/faces/Warning. jspx.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date(s): February 11, 2016 (Direct) and December 9, 2015
§ 3.4(b)(4) Outdoor Housing Facilities.

Shelter from the elements. Outdoor facilities for dogs or cats must include one or more shelter structures
that are accessible to each animal in each outdoor facility, and that are large enough to allow each animal in
the shelter structure to sit, stand, and lie in a normal manner, and to turn about freely. In addition to the
shelter structures, one or more separate outside areas of shade must be provided, large enough to contain all
the animals at one time and protect them from the direct rays of the sun. Shelters in outdoor facilities for
dogs or cats must contain a roof, four sides, and a floor, and must provide the dogs and cats with protection
from the direct rays of the sun and the direct effect of wind, rain, or snow.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

https.//acissearch.aphis.usda. gov/LPASearch/faces/Warning. js,

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions,
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

§ 3.1(c)(1)(ii) — Housing Facilities, General.

Surfaces. General requirements. The surfaces of housing facilities — including houses, dens, and other
furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility —- must be constructed in a manner and made of
materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and sanitized, or removed or replaced when worn or soiled.
Interior surfaces and any surfaces that come in contact with dogs and cats must be free of jagged edges or
sharp points that might injure the animals,

§ 3.1(c)(2) — Housing Facilities, General.

Surfaces. Maintenance and replacement of surfaces. All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis,
Surfaces of housing facilities — including houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures and objects within
the facility — that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled.

prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases, Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above, Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice,

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date(s): May 27, 2016 and July 09, 2015
§ 2.1(a)(1) - Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,
except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section,
must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a
license shall apply on a form which will be furnished by the AC Regional Director in the State in which that
person operates or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at
all times, and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records may be
inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional
Director.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that

your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection

reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

https://acissearch.aphis.usda gow/LPASearch/faces/Warning.js
The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any

further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

§ 3.53 - Primary enclosures. (DIRECT)

All primary enclosures for rabbits shall conform to the following requirements: primary enclosures
shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the rabbits from injury, to contain them,
and to keep predators out.

§ 3.125(a) - Facilities, general.

Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as
appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound
and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

Date(s): March 28, 2016 and December 07, 2015
§ 2.40(b)(2) - Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). (DIRECT)

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that
include: the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

§ 2.40(b)(2) — Attending Veterinarian and Adequate Veterinary Care. (DIRECT)

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include
the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:
h ‘ch.aphis. ’

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases, Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions,
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed

below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: Between January 2014-December 2014

9 C.F.R. § 2.1(a)(1) Requirements of Application. Any person operating or intending to
operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale, except persons who are
exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section, must
have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A
person seeking a license shall apply on a form which will be furnished by the AC
Regional Director in the State in which that person operates or intends to operate. The
applicant shall provide the information requested on the application form, including a
valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at all times,
and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records
may be inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application
form with the AC Regional Director.

You operated as a dealer without first obtaining a valid license. You sold
three juvenile lemurs for $500.

Date of Violation: On or about October 2014

may be inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application
form with the AC Regional Director.

§ 3.125(a) - Facilities, general.
Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as

appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound
and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

§ 3.127(c) - Facilities, outdoor. DIRECT

Drainage. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water. The method of
drainage shall comply with applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations relating to pollution
control or the protection of the environment.

§ 2.1 - Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,
except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section,
must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a
license shall apply on a form which will be furnished by the AC Regional Director in the State in which that
person operates or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at
all times, and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records may be
inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional
Director.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

§ 2.40(b)(2) - Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). (DIRECT)

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that
include: the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

hitps://acissearch.aphis. usda. gow/L PASearch/fuces/Warning js

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Waming for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

§ 3.31(a)(1) - Sanitation.

Cleaning and sanitation of primary enclosures. Primary enclosures shall be cleaned and sanitized
often enough to prevent an accumulation of excreta or debris: Provided, however, That such enclosures shall
be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks in the manner provided in paragraph (a)(4) of this section.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date(s): January 07, 2016 and April 30, 2015
§ 2.31(c)(6) - Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee TACUC).
IACUC functions. With respect to activities involving animals, the IACUC, as an agent of the research

facility, shall: review and approve, require modifications in (to secure approval), or withhold approval of
those components of proposed activities related to the care and use of animals.

§ 2.31(c)(7) - Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).

IACUC functions. With respect to activities involving animals, the IACUC, as an agent of the research
facility, shall: review and approve, require modifications in (to secure approval), or withhold approval of
proposed significant changes regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities.

§ 3.11(c) - Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.

Housekeeping for premises. Premises where housing facilities are located, including buildings and
surrounding grounds, must be kept clean and in good repair to protect the animals from injury, to facilitate
the husbandry practices required in this subpart, and to reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for
rodents and other pests and vermin. Premises must be kept free of accumulations of trash, junk, waste
products, and discarded matter. Weeds, grasses, and bushes must be controlled so as to facilitate cleaning of
the premises and pest control, and to protect the health and well-being of the animals.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

Attps:/acissearch.aphis.usda.gowLPASearch/faces/Warning. jspx,

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your

Date(s): April 26, 2016
§ 2.32(a) — Personnel Qualifications.

It shall be the responsibility of the research facility to ensure that all scientists, research technicians,
animal technicians, and other personnel involved in animal care, treatment, and use are qualified to perform
their duties. This responsibility shall be fulfilled in part through the provision of training and instruction to
those personnel.

§ 2,33(b)(2) — Attending Veterinarian and Adequate Veterinary Care.

Each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include
the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(d) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any

clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts

Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

; a A : (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 16, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(d) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the rule criteria shall be
considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of the Act.

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (7 )(C) (b) (6 )

rnin (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)
OFPECIAL WARNING

VIOLATION OF FEDERAIZREGULATIONS TOURED (Street, City, State, ZIP
; eA (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

po patty Pos Eh (b) (7)(C), (6) (6)

ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)

OF PECIAL WARNING
VIOLATION OF DERA REGUL ATIONS ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP
3 Ne ; ‘f : (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

iscsi tc le (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)

Version: Final


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_62
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are
detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for
the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions. If
you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact
the APHIS official listed in this notice.

USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name):
Steve Bennett

ANS A (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

Pa s y. :

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: May 18, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)

Issuance Date: August 5. 2016
Version: Final


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_100
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

Steve Bennett

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below,
you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or sold
at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering for the
purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition; or
offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing
any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by
regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of
horses.”

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,

except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_120
The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are
detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for
the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions. If
you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact
the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

Date(s): 2016

§ 3.125(a) Facilities, General.

Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as
appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound
and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

hitps://acissearch.aphis.usda.gowLPASearch/faces/Warning.is

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

ANIMAL AND PLANT seu INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (7 \(C), , (b) (6)

% e FA = (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: July 11, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts

“The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any
horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in
any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling,
auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse which
is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or (C)
respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

Date of Violation: July 11, 2015
9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Scar Rule

“The scar rule applies to all horses born on or after October 1, 1975. Horses
subject to this rule that do not meet the...scar rule criteria shall be considered
to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of...the Act.”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

pineal (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)
| as oe August 10, 2016 |


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_141
USDA

—

a
United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:
Steve Bennett 4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737
APHIS OFFICIAL (Title): eo ISSUED: TELEPHONE
i j isati i 8/10/2016 :
Acting Director, Investigative and Enforcement Services (301) 851-2948

APHIS FORM 7060 Previous editions may be used Rev. 7-26-13

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer

Issuance Date: August 10, 2016
Version: Final

auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse which

below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 8, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)

criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

SHULaition oe - ; ats EGULATIONS ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP
Sew 5 (b) (6), (8) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 8, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_163
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

Riverdale, MD 20737

VIOLATION OE ik DERAIZREG ULATIONS ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP
; bh Na ; (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: July 5, 2014
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering

for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: July 5, 2014
9 C.F.R. § 11.2 (c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors - Substance

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed

below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: April 25, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any

clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Scar Rule. Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar

tule criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section
5 of the Act.

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse

Date of Violation: April 24, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or exhibition; or offering for
sale at a horse show or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any equipment,
device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828
of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

tiateaicrioaie (b) (7)(C), (6) (6)

Issuance Date: August 9, 2016
Version: Final


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_205
USDA

—

am
United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

Regulations:

Date of Violation: April 24, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_227
USDA

—

am
United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

; ‘NS ae & (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 1, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore.

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 1, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The
(A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is
sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

The scar rule applies to all horses born on or after October 1, 1975. Horses
subject to this rule that do not meet the...scar rule criteria shall be considered to
be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of...the Act.”

OFFICIAL WARNING

VIOLATION OF, FEDERAL;REG ULATIONS ROOD lant Cay Sie 2

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 28, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore.

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

Riverdale, MD 20737

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official

regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)

OFFICIAL Wy. ING

VIOLATION OF FEDERAL EGULATIONS ee (Street Cily, State, ZIP
> (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 28, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: “(2) The
(A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is
sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

a.  «F;

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 27, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The (B)
entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition,
any horse which is sore.

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or
horse exhibition ; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be
shown, exhibited, sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction the
entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition;
or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any
equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under
section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

9 C.F.R. § 11(2)(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances. All substances
are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any Tennessee Walking Horse or
racking horse while being show, exhibited, or offered for sale at any horse show, horse
exhibition, or horse sale or auction, except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and
mineral oil, or mixtures thereof. ...”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

cbaipcaipsrwitai (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)

United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 27, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The (B)
entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition,
any horse which is sore.

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The
(A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is
sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 31, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824 (2) Unlawful Acts

“The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any
horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any
horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning,
or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D)
allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse
which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

Date of Violation: August 31, 2015
9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Scar Rule

“The scar rule applies to all horses born on or after October 1, 1975. Horses
subject to this rule that do not meet the...scar rule criteria shall be considered to
be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of...the Act.”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

An Equal OpparuntyProwter nd Eiploye (b) (7)(C), (b) (6)

Issuance Date: August 18. 2016
Version: Final


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_279
The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are
detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for
the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions. If
you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact
the APHIS official listed in this notice.

VIOLATION OF FEDERAIZREGULATIONS ADDRESS (Street. City. State. ZIP Code).

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below,
you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 29, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts

“The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any
horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any
horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning,
or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D)
allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse
which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

Date of Violation: August 29, 2015
9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Scar Rule

“The scar rule applies to all horses born on or after October 1, 1975. Horses
subject to this rule that do not meet the...scar rule criteria shall be considered to
be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of...the Act.”

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_299
The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are
detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for
the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions. If
you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact
the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS: j

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 29, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

Date of Violation: September 1, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Prohibited substances

The following conduct is prohibited:

(7) The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the
selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction;
the entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or
horse exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse
which is wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or
substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828 of this title
prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: July 1, 2016
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or
(C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

Gary Edwards was the custodian who entered for the purpose of showing
“Honors” (class number 40, entry number 877) while sore at the Christmas in
July horse show in Shelbyville, Tennessee.

am
United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: July 1, 2016
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts - Entering

The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition,
of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)
selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse
which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_318
USDA

—

am
United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:
Steve Bennett 4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_340

am
United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests

that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

> eS (b) (6), (b) (7(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 1, 2015
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(A) Unlawful acts - Showing

Sec. 1824. Unlawful acts
The following conduct is prohibited:

(2) The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse
exhibition, of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing
or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore,
(C) selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any
horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in clause (A),
(B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

Issuance Date: August 11. 2016

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_383
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name):
Steven M. Bennett

Director, Investigative and Enforcement Services (301) 851-2948

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests

other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

sun aTNe re’ " R & R Research LLC

OFFICIAL WARNING Customer# 45412

TON OT Ih License# 91-A-0113
VIOLATION OF i EDE RAL REGU LATIONS ADDRESS (Sieel Cl State, ZIP Codey:

? ee Mt,” 20004 Happy Valley Road
A, st Stanwood, WA 98292

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date(s): August 5, 2015
§ 2.40(b)(3) Attending Veterinarian and Adequate Veterinary Care. (DIRECT)

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include
daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily
observation of animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and
Provided, further, That a mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending
veterinarian.

Date(s): August 5, 2015 and December 3, 2015

§ 3.53(a)(1) Primary Enclosures.

Primary enclosures shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the rabbits from
injury, to contain them, and to keep predators out.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

Aitps://acissearch.aphis.usda.govw/LP ASearch/faces/Warning. js,

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you haye any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: October 17, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You entered a horse named (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

where the horse was found sore and in
violation of the scar rule.

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts

violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: September 25, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition ; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction the entering for
the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition; or offering
for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any equipment,
device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828
of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

9 C.F.R. § 11(2)(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors — Substances. All substances are
prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any Tennessee Walking Horse or racking
horse while being show, exhibited, or offered for sale at any horse show, horse
exhibition, or horse sale or auction, except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and
mineral oil, or mixtures thereof....”

Reference Number:(b) (6), (b) (7(C)

9 C.F.R. § 11(3)(b) Scar rule. The posterior surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface),
including the sulcus of “pocket” may show bilateral areas of uniformly thickened
epithelial tissue if such areas are free of proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation,
moisture, edema, or other evidence of inflammation.

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

the horse was found sore, in violation of the scar rule, and
bearing a prohibited substance on the pasterns during a pre-show inspection.

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts

regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.
