## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_401
USDA

—

am
United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

ORFICIAL WARNING (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

VIOLATION OF FEDERAL REGULATIONS

Pee ee

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C) ; Cc
Date(s): 1016 and on 2046
§ 2.40(a)(1) - Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).

Each dealer or exhibitor shall have an attending veterinarian who shall provide adequate veterinary
care to its animals in compliance with this section. Each dealer and exhibitor shall employ an attending
veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time attending veterinarian or consultant
arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and regularly
scheduled visits to the premises of the dealer or exhibitor.

(b) (6), (©) (7)(C)
Date(s): 2016
§ 2.40(b)(3) - Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). (DIRECT)

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that
include: daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily
observation of animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and
Provided, further, That a mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending
veterinarian.

b) (Myq4 6

Date(s): e916 and”) |
§ 3.50(a) - Facilities, general.

Structural strength. Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for rabbits shall be structurally sound and
shall be maintained in good repair, to protect the animals from injury, to contain the animals, and to restrict
the entrance of other animals.

§ 3.125(a) - Facilities, general.
Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as

appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound
and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_403
§ 3.131(c) - Sanitation.

Housekeeping. Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to
protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.
Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of
the animals.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

hitps:‘/acissearch.aphis.usda.gow/LP ASearch/faces/Warning.is

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The following conduct is prohibited:

of any horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or
exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C)

to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below,
you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or sold
at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering for the
purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition; or
offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing
any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by
regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of
horses.”

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
9 C.F.R. § 11.2(c) Prohibition conceming exhibitors — Substances

“All substances are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any
Tennessee Walking Horse or racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or
offered for sale at any horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction,
except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and mineral oil, or mixtures
thereof...”
(b) (6), (0) (7X) entered, for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse, °°""""”
which was found to be
wearing a foreign substance.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_427
The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are
detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for
the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions. If
you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact
the APHIS official listed in this notice.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_428

ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

VIOLATION OF SDERAUIEGULATION Ss

CASE NUMBER:
(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

Suz (b) (6), (6) (7)(C)
é \ . na e ?
OFF L-WARNENG
ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP

Code):
ne I thy (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts

“The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse exhibition; the selling or
auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown, exhibited, or
sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition; or offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is
wearing or bearing any equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which
the Secretary by regulation under Section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent
the soring of horses.”

Date of Violation: May 19, 2013

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,

the Act.

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The

(A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is
sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

to be entered for the purpose of showing while in violation of scar

Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 31, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is
sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described
in clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition; or
offering for sale at a horse sale or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any
equipment, device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under
section 1828 of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

9 C.F.R. § 11(2)(c) Prohibition concerning exhibitors - Substances. All substances
are prohibited on the extremities above the hoof of any Tennessee Walking Horse or
racking horse while being shown, exhibited, or offered for sale at any horse show, horse
exhibition, or horse sale or auction, except lubricants such as glycerine, petrolatum, and
mineral oil, or mixtures thereof. ...”

9 C.F.R. § 11(3)(b) Scar rule. The posterior surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface),
including the sulcus of “pocket” may show bilateral areas of uniformly thickened
epithelial tissue if such areas are free of proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation,
moisture, edema, or other evidence of inflammation.

(b) (8). (b) (7KC)

(b) (6), (6) (7C) entered for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse

where the horse was found
in violation of the scar rule, and bearing a prohibited substance on the pasterns
during a pre-show inspection.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal
Regulations:

Date of Violation: August 26, 2016

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You showed a horse named “(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
while the

horse was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

United States Department of Agriculture

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about (0) (6), (©) (C914, you or your organization
committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

3.53(a) Primary Enclosures.....primary enclosures shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury, to contain them and to keep predators out (DIRECT)

You failed to maintain structurally sound primary enclosures. Rabbit enclosures are not structurally
sound, wire floors have holes up to 4 inches wide, wire mesh on wall and tops have broken ends
extending into enclosures. Solid walls have holes, are rusted and have peeling paint.

3.55 Watering....sufficient potable water daily except as might otherwise be required to provide adequate veterinary
care. All watering receptacles shall be sanitized when dirty (repeat)

You failed to sanitize rabbit water bottles hanging on cages have a heavy buildup of algae.
3.56(a)(1)Sanitation....primary enclosures for animals reasonably free of excreta, hair cobwebs and other debris by
periodic cleaning (repeat)

You failed to clean primary enclosures. Rabbit enclosures have a buildup of excreta, especially in corners

and along edges.

3.127(a) Facilities, Outdoor ....when sunlight is likely to cause overheating or discomfort of the animals kept
outdoors by providing sufficient shade by natural or artificial means. (DIRECT)

You failed to provide sufficient shade. All animals in the lower level goat / sheep pen, housing mothers and

kids, could not fit in the shade area. The animals were crowed in the shade area reducing its effectiveness.
3.131(a) Sanitation... excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to contamination of
the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce adors (repeat)

You failed to remove excreta as necessary. The llama / alpaca pen and the pygmy goat pen both had heavy
buildup of excreta.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty. criminal prosecution. or other sanctions.
If you have any questions conceming this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

The Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about 013 and 2014 you or
your organization committed the following violation of Federal Regulations:

9 CFR, SECTION

2.40(b)(2)

Failure to

e Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain
programs of adequate veterinary care that include: The use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat
diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency,
weekend, and holiday care.

Several guinea pigs were observed with eye abnormalities and skin
lesions. The veterinarian had not been contacted prior to inspection.
**Grey guinea pig in pen 45 had greyish mucus discharge around
outside of left eye.

**Black and white guinea pig in pen 32 had left eye completely closed
with crusty discharge and swollen.

**Black and white guinea pig in pen 8 had partially closed right eye
and white mucus discharge from lower lid.

**Black and white guinea pig in pen 29 had skin lesions around right
eye and on top of the nose. Dark red to black crusty areas consistent
with scabs/dried blood and small amounts of fresh blood were
present.

**Tri-color guinea pig in pen 4 had skin lesions on the left hip. Small
red to black color scabs and moderate hair loss in the area.

**White guinea pig in pen 45 had skin lesions around the right eye
with dry flaky skin in the lower corner of the eye. Hair loss and a
few small red scab-like lesions were in the area.

**Tri-color guinea pig in pen 48 had skin lesions on top of the nose,
cluster of small red color scabs with moderate hair loss and dry flaky
skin.

**White guinea pig in pen 50 had skin lesions around the left eye
with dry flaky skin and hair loss in lower corner of the eye.

**Left eye of a black and white guinea pig in pen 4 had cloudy
appearance. Opaque white flakes were seen in center of cornea.
**Brown and white guinea pig in pen 29 had skin lesions around
right eye and on top of the nose. Skin under lower left eye lid was
dry and flaky with hair loss.

3.1(c)(3) Housing Facilities, General....hard surfaces with which the animals come into contact must be spot-clean
daily and sanitize once every two weeks

doors.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_473
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:

ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE NE130012-AC
VIOLATOR:
Pet Air Carrier, L.L.C.
OFFICIAL WARNING
VIOLATION OF FEDERAIZREGULATIONS ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP Code):

Roswell, GA 30075

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below,
you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: February 4, 2013

9 C.F.R. § 3.140(a) Care in Transit. During surface transportation, it shall be the
responsibility of the driver or other employee to visually observe the live animals as
frequently as circumstances may dictate, but not less than once every 4 hours, to assure
that they are receiving sufficient air for normal breathing, their ambient temperatures are
within the prescribed limits, all other applicable standards are being complied with and to
determine whether any of the live animals are in obvious physical distress and to provide
any needed veterinary care as soon as possible. When transported by air, live animals shall
be visually observed by the carrier as frequently as circumstances may dictate, but not less
than once every 4 hours, if the animal cargo space is accessible during flight. If the animal
cargo space is not accessible during flight, the carrier shall visually observe the live
animals whenever loaded and unloaded and whenever the animal cargo space is otherwise
accessible to assure that they are receiving sufficient air for normal breathing, their
ambient temperatures are within the prescribed limits, all other applicable standards are
being complied with and to determine whether any such live animals are in obvious
physical distress. The carrier shall provide any needed veterinary care as soon as possible.
No animal in obvious physical distress shall be transported in commerce.

You transported two crates of piglets from a consignor in Sioux Center, Iowa to
Atlanta, Georgia. Each crate was covered with a commercially available nylon
cover which specifically fit the crate used and was designed to protect the
animals from extreme weather. The cover was insulated, and enclosed the entire
crate, including the ventilation holes. When you picked up the animals at the
Atlanta airport to deliver them to their final destination, you failed to visually
observe the animals in both crates. At the time of delivery, all 10 piglets in one
of the crates were deceased.


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_474
The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are
detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for
the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions. If
you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact
the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

(6) (6), (b) (7)(C)

OFFICIAL WARNING

The Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about (9) (6), (b) (7)(C), 2014 you or your
organization committed the following violation of Federal Regulations:

9 CFR, SECTION Failure to

2.38(H(1) e Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and

carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma,
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical
harm, or unnecessary discomfort.

(On February 2, 2014 a groundhog on exhibition as part of

groundhog day celebration managed to escape from the hands of an

untrained person and fell to the ground. The same groundhog

escaped and fell from its handler during use as an educational animal

in a school a about week later. On February 9, 2014 the groundhog

was found deceased.)

Titles 7 & 9 Code of Federal Regulations were promulgated to help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases and assure the humane treatment of animals. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly
impact detrimental to the public interest, you are warned of this violation. Any further violation of these regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty or criminal prosecution. If you have any questions concerning this warning or
violation, please contact the listed APHIS Official.

The Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about August 29, 2012, June 17, 2014 and July
18, 2014 you or your organization committed the following violation of Federal Regulations:

9 CFR, SECTION Failure to

2.38(H(1) e Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and

carefully as possible in a mannger that does not cause trauma,
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical
harm, or unnecessary discomfort.

(**On August 29, 2012 the facility failed to ensure transfer of all

guinea pigs to a new cage rack resulting in the death of one animal.

The valve of the watering system was not fully closed allowing water

to leak into and flood the cage.

**On June 17, 2014 three guinea pigs were found deceased in their

cage after a leak in the watering system flooded the cage overnight.

**On July 18, 2014 a guinea pig cage flooded overnight resulting in

the death of one guinea pig.)

Titles 7 & 9 Code of Federal Regulations were promulgated to help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases and assure the humane treatment of animals. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly
impact detrimental to the public interest, you are warned of this violation. Any further violation of these regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty or criminal prosecution. If you have any questions concerning this warning or
violation, please contact the listed APHIS Official.

committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

2.33(b)(2) Attending Veterinarian and Adequate Vet Care.... each research facility shall establish and

maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that use the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose,
and treat diseases and injuries (DIRCET)

You failed to provide veterinarian care for the following animals:

-A male beagle (Microchip #2576) was extremely thin and not receiving treatment

-A female beagle (Microchip #0A02413257) had a large, red swelling located in the inner corner of the
right eye, on the inner surface of the lower eyelid

-A female beagle (Microchip #0A02412566) was extremely wobbly and ataxic, appeared disoriented and
had difficulty walking

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_482
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

VIOLATOR:
Seattle Children’s Research Institute
Registration #: 91-R-0059

Customer #: 1268
ADDRESS (Sireel, City, State, ZIP Code):

1900 — 9" Avenue
Seattle, WA 98101

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about July 23, 2014 and November 26, 2013, you or
your organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

2.31(d)(1) Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (ACUC)....repeated failure to
follow the approved procedures involving more than momentary pain and distress and follow the
[ACUC approved protocol and animals to receive appropriate anesthesia or analgesia

On 3/12/14 in Cage ID "Acomys 2", two males had several fight wounds, including "right axillary (very deep, able to
visualize muscle)". The Attending Veterinarian recommended carprofen gel, which is specified in the protocol as
appropriate analgesia. The research group requested no treatment. Five days later there is a notation that the
investigator requested no carprofen gel due to the mouse having a cranial cap. This is despite the fact that the
protocol lists carprofen as a specified appropriate analgesic for this procedure.

On 3/12/14 in Cage ID "Acomys 10” there is a notation that two males have several fight wounds, and one has a leg
wound with intermittent lameness. The Attending Veterinarian recommends carprofen gel for 5 to 7 days for the lame
mouse. There is a request for the research team to approve this treatment within 20 hours. Two days later one mouse
was euthanized, and the other "recovered". No analgesics appear to have been administered.

On 4/16/14 in Cage ID "Acomys 42B" there were two pups noted with "multiple large surface area lesions (superficial
to moderate)". The Attending Veterinarian recommends treatment with Carprofen ge! for two to three days. The next
day the research team replied that they “declined carprofen gel at this time".

In the 5/13/14 IACUC meeting minutes these same researches request a modification to the protocol to "remove anti-
inflammatory agents" for part of the study, in order to "elucidate the differences in inflammatory responses".

On 11/26/13 is observed that at least 6 pigs used in an IACUC protocol experienced unnecessary pain and distress
which may have contributed to their deaths

These examples demonstrate that the research team was not following the IACUC-approved protocol

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help

prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that

are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any

further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.

if you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.
APHIS OFFICIAL (ame and Title): OFFICE ADDRESS:

Chester A. Gipson Not a FOIA Deletion 4700 River Road

Deputy Administrato Riverdale, MD 30737

11/5/14 (970)494-7478

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_484
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

CASE NUMBER:
IL150028-AC

ALLEGED VIOLATOR:
SPOT Travel, LLC
C/O SPOT Group
Holdings, LLC
OFFICIAL. WARNING

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):
New York, NY 10011

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: June 18-19, 2015
9 C.F.R. § 2.131(b)(1) Handling of Animals.

You failed to handle animals as carefully as possible in a manner that did not
cause trauma, overheating, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary
discomfort. A shipment of four adult sugar gliders were scheduled for
transport by a carrier, in commerce, from Charlotte-Douglas International
Airport (CLT), routed through Chicago, Illinois (ORD), with a final
destination of Charleston, West Virginia (CRW). The carrier did not load the
animals onto their originally-scheduled flight from CLT to ORD, and
subsequently transported them on a later flight to ORD. Due to the missed
flight and weather-related delays, the sugar gliders did not make their
connection to CRW, and the carrier delivered them to you for holding
overnight at ORD. You did not visually observe the sugar gliders or provide
them with food or water. The sugar gliders resumed transit on a flight from
ORD to CRW the following day, and the consignee discovered that they were
dead when she picked them up at CRW. The necropsy performed on the sugar
gliders indicated that they died from probable heat stroke.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: IL150028-AC
Issuance Date: November 14,

2016
Version: Final



## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_485
USDA
Sars

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warning for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_486
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (6), (b) (7\(C)
ALLEGED VIOLATOR:

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

ADDRESS (City. State, Z/P Code):

OFFICIAL. WARNING (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: September 19, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.”

You allowed your horse (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

while the horse was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

Date of Violation: September 19, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or exhibition; or offering for
sale at a horse show or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any equipment,
device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828
of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

You allowed your horse (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

where the horse was wearing a black foreign substance.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_490
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:

ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
VIOLATOR:
9 (1) (6), (b) (7)(C)
OFFICIAL WARNING

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below,
you or your organization committed the following violation(s) of Federal Regulations:

Date of Violation: May 4, 2013
15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts

“The (A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any
horse which is sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any
horse show or horse exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning,
or offering for sale, in any horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D)
allowing any activity described in clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse
which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C) showed the horse, (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
while the horse was sore.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to
ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and
diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that are
detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for
the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal regulations may
result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions. If
you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact
the APHIS official listed in this notice.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_494
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warning for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_508
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warning for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_511
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
ALLEGED VIOLATOR:

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):

OFFICIAL.WARNING (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: October 8, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Scar Rule. Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar
rule criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section
5 of the Act.

You allowed your horse (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

while the horse was sore.

Date of Violation: October 8, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(7) Unlawful Acts. The showing or exhibiting at a horse show or horse
exhibition; the selling or auctioning at a horse sale or auction; the allowing to be shown,
exhibited, or sold at a horse show, horse exhibition, or horse sale or auction; the entering
for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or exhibition; or offering for
sale at a horse show or auction, any horse which is wearing or bearing any equipment,
device, paraphernalia, or substance which the Secretary by regulation under section 1828
of this title prohibits to prevent the soring of horses.

You allowed your horse named (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

here the horse was wearing a black
foreign substance.

Reference Number: (2) (6), (b) (7)(C)
Issuance Date: November 4, 2016
Version: Final

regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE

CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (

R:
b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

ALLEGED VIOLATOR:
(b) (6), (b) (7(C)

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):

OFFICIAL.WARNING (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: October 10, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule
criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.”

You allowed your horse (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

while the horse was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_546
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warning for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

DATE ISSUED: | TELEPHONE
11/18/2016 | NUMBER:
301) 851-2948

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE

CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (

R:
b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

ALLEGED VIOLATOR:
(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):

OFFICIAL.WARNING (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: October 10, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2) Unlawful Acts. The following conduct is prohibited: The (A)
showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is sore,
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule

criteria shall be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of
the Act.

You showed a horse named (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
while
the horse was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

CASE NUMBER:
(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

ALLEGED VIOLATOR:

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

OFFICIAL. WARNING
NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: October 16, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The
(A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is
sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.

allowed a horse you eta. sisnned (0) (6), (b) (7)(C)

You
(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)vhich was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

Date of Violation: October 16, 2015

9 C.LF.R.§ 11.3. Scar rule. The scar rule applies to all horses born on or after October
1, 1975. Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule criteria shall
be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of the Act. The
scar rule criteria are as follows: (a) The anterior and anterior-lateral surfaces of the fore
pasterns (extensor surface) must be free of bilateral granulomas,5 other bilateral
pathological evidence of inflammation, and, other bilateral evidence of abuse indicative
of soring including, but not limited to, excessive loss of hair. (b) The posterior surfaces
of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus or “pocket” may show bilateral
areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of proliferating
granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of inflammation.

You allowed a horse you own named “(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

which was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

Reference Number: (P) (6), (b) (7)(C)
Issuance Date: November 10, 2016
Version: Final

9 C.F.R.§ 11.3. Scar rule. The scar rule applies to all horses born on or after October
1, 1975. Horses subject to this rule that do not meet the following scar rule criteria shall
be considered to be “sore” and are subject to all prohibitions of section 5 of the Act. The
scar rule criteria are as follows: (a) The anterior and anterior-lateral surfaces of the fore
pasterns (extensor surface) must be free of bilateral granulomas,5 other bilateral
pathological evidence of inflammation, and, other bilateral evidence of abuse indicative
of soring including, but not limited to, excessive loss of hair. (b) The posterior surfaces
of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus or “pocket” may show bilateral
areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of proliferating
granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of inflammation.

You showed a horse named “(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

which was sore and in violation of the scar rule.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_564
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

OFFICE ADDRESS:
4700 River Road, Unit 85
Riverdale, MD 20737

APHIS OFFICIAL (Name):
Steven M. Bennett

APHIS OFFICIAL (Title): ar issue: TELEPHONE
1 igati i 11/8/2016 :

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_566
USDA
Sears

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations
to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and plant pests
and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts
that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official
Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any further violation of these federal
regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or
other sanctions. If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or
violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: August 28, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The
(B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which is sore.

9 C.F.R. § 11.3(b) Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: “The posterior
surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

(b) (8). (b) (71C)

(b) (6), (6) (7(C) entered for the purpose of showing or exhibiting, the horse

, Where the horse was
found sore and in violation of the scar rule.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warning for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.

(A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is

exhibition, any horse which is sore, (C) selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any

surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus of “pocket” may show
bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas are free of
proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence of
inflammation.”

regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and

sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
Date(s): 2016

§ 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,
except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section,
must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a
license shall apply on a form which will be furnished by the AC Regional Director in the State in which that
person operates or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at
all times, and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records may be
inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional
Director.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at:

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases, Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions,
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

§ 3.52(a) Facilities, outdoor, (Critical)

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

oO

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
Date(s): 2016

§ 2.40(b)(3) — Attending Veterinarian and Adequate Veterinary Care.

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include
daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily
observation of animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and
Provided, further, That a mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending
veterinarian.

§ 3.125(a) — Facilities, General.
Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as

appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound
and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

§ 3.133 — Separation.

Animals housed in the same primary enclosure must be compatible. Animals shall not be housed near
animals that interfere with their health or cause them discomfort.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at: https://acis.aphis.edc.usda.gov/ords/f?p=116:1:9172609945732.

§ 2.131(c)(1) Handling of Animals.

During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal
and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public
so as to assure the safety of animals and the public.

§ 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,
except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section,
must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a
license shall apply on a form which will be furnished by the AC Regional Director in the State in which that
person operates or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at
all times, and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records may be
inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional
Director.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations. Inspection
reports can be found on APHIS’ website at: https://acis.aphis.edc.usda.gov/ords/f?p=1 16: 1:9172609945732.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please a the APHIS official listed in this notice.

§ 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,
except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section,
must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a
license shall apply on a form which will be furnished by the AC Regional Director in the State in which that
person operates or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at
all times, and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records may be
inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional
Director.

§ 2.131(c)(1) Handling of animals. (Critical)

During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal
and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public
so as to assure the safety of animals and the public.

§ 2.131(d)(2) Handling of animals. (Critical)

A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all
times during periods of public contact.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_603
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER:
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

% ee

[ ANNRESS (Straat City State, ZIP Code):

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

b) (6), (b) (7)(C
Date(s): 2016 (REPEAT)

§ 3.1(c)(1)(i) Housing facilities, general.

General requirements. The surfaces of housing facilities — including houses, dens, and other furniture-
type fixtures and objects within the facility — must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that
allow them to be readily cleaned and sanitized, or removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Interior
surfaces and any surfaces that come in contact with dogs or cats must be free of excessive rust that prevents
the required cleaning and sanitization, or that affects the structural strength of the surface.

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
Date(s): 2016 (REPEAT)

§ 3.9(b) Feeding.

Food receptacles must be used for dogs and cats, must be readily accessible to all dogs and cats, and
must be located so as to minimize contamination by excreta and pests, and be protected from rain and snow,
Feeding pans must either be made of a durable material that can be easily cleaned and sanitized or be
disposable. If the food receptacles are not disposable, they must be kept clean and must be sanitized in
accordance with § 3.11(b) of this subpart. Sanitization is achieved by using one of the methods described in
§ 3.11(b)(3) of this subpart. If the food receptacles are disposable, they must be discarded after one use. Self-
feeders may be used for the feeding of dry food. If self-feeders are used, they must be kept clean and must be
sanitized in accordance with § 3.11(b) of this subpart. Measures must be taken to ensure that there is no
molding, deterioration, and caking of feed.

b) (6), (b Cc
Date(s):| (8), (©) (M 016 (REPEAT)

§ 3.11(a) Cleaning, sanitation, housekeeping, and pest control.

Cleaning of primary enclosures. Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures
daily, and from under primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of
feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the dogs or cats contained in the primary enclosures, and to
reduce disease hazards, insects, pests and odors, When steam or water is used to clean the primary enclosure,
whether by hosing, flushing, or other methods, dogs and cats must be removed, unless the enclosure is large
enough to ensure the animals would not be harmed, wetted, or distressed in the process. Standing water must
be removed from the primary enclosure and animals in other primary enclosures must be protected from

An Equal Opportunity: Provider and Employer


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_604
being contaminated with water and other wastes during the cleaning. The pans under primary enclosures
with grill-type floors and the ground areas under raised runs with mesh or slatted floors must be cleaned as
often as necessary to prevent accumulation of feces and food waste and to reduce disease hazards pests,

insects and odors.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_605
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE

CASE NUMBER:
MN150006

VIOLATOR:
In-Sync Exotics Inc.
. Customer# 7901

CULATIONS License# 74-C-0431

ADDRESS (Street, City, State, ZIP Code):
P.O. Box 968
Wylie, TX 75098

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your organization
committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

Date: September 13, 2014
§ 3.140(a) — Care in transit.

During surface transportation, it shall be the responsibility of the driver or other employee to visually observe the live
animals as frequently as circumstances may dictate, but not less than once every 4 hours, to assure that they are
receiving sufficient air for normal breathing, their ambient temperatures are within the prescribed limits, all other
applicable standards are being complied with and to determine whether any of the live animals are in obvious physical
distress and to provide any needed veterinary care as soon as possible.

You failed to seek veterinary care as soon as possible for a caracal named Ivan that was in obvious physical
distress during transit. An employee noticed vomit on the floor of the caracal’s enclosure during transit and
observed that Ivan did not appear to be acting normally and was resting his head on the floor. Approximately
three hours prior to arrival, Ivan was observed to have trouble walking. You did not seek veterinary care as
soon as possible for Ivan during transit and Ivan was found unresponsive upon arrival to the destination.

Animal Care believes signs of obvious physical stress were readily observable but a veterinarian was not
contacted to provide direction on adequate and needed care as soon as possible. It is your responsibility to
ensure all applicable standards are being complied with including, but not limited to, determining whether any
live animals are in obvious physical stress and providing any needed veterinary care as soon as possible.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that your
facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help

prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that

are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any

further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.

If you have any questions conceming this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.
APHIS OFFICIAL (Name): OFFICE ADDRESS:

Gerald Rushin 4700 River Road
Riverdale, MD 30737

Date(s): June 6, 2016
§ 3.1(a) Housing facilities, general. (Critical)

Structure; construction. Housing facilities for dogs and cats must be designed and constructed so that they are
structurally sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the

animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.

Date(s): June 6, 2016

§ 3.125(a) Facilities, general. (Critical)

Structural strength. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the
animals involved. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in
good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
lyour facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations.

§ 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,
except persons who are exempted from the licensing requirements under paragraph (a)(3) of this section,
must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a

person operates or intends to operate. The applicant shall provide the information requested on the
application form, including a valid mailing address through which the licensee or applicant can be reached at

all times, and a valid premises address where animals, animal facilities, equipment, and records may be
inspected for compliance. The applicant shall file the completed application form with the AC Regional
Director.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

§ 2.1(a)(1) Requirements and application.

Any person operating or intending to operate as a dealer, exhibitor, or operator of an auction sale,

must have a valid license. A person must be 18 years of age or older to obtain a license. A person seeking a

§ 3.11(b)(2) - Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. (Critical)

accumulation of dirt, debris. food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards,

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed below, you or your
organization committed violations of the following sections of the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 9:

6), (b) (7)(C

Date(s): 016

§ 2.40(b)(3) - Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). (DIRECT)

Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that
include: the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the
availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
Date(s): 2016 and?" 2016

§ 3.31(a)(2) - Sanitation. (DIRECT REPEAT)

Cleaning and sanitation of primary enclosures. In the event a primary enclosure becomes soiled or wet
to a degree that might be harmful or uncomfortable to the animals therein due to leakage of the watering
system, discharges from dead or dying animals, spoiled perishable foods, or moisture condensation, the
guinea pigs or hamsters shall be transferred to clean primary enclosures.

Date(s): © © © 2916, and © ©) ©) MO 9145

§ 3.31(b) - Sanitation. (REPEAT)

Housekeeping. Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to
protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.
Premises shall remain free of accumulations of trash.

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

Date(s): oe 9016 and 2016 (Only use the dates that the actually repeat was cited)

§ 2.75(b)(1) - Records: Dealers and exhibitors. (REPEAT)

Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and
exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following
information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held,
leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold,
euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born
of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and- Employer


## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_614
Date(s): (b) (6), (b) 5916
§ 3.29(d) - Feeding. (REPEAT)

Food receptacles, if used, shall be accessible to all guinea pigs or hamsters in a primary enclosure and
shall be located so as to minimize contamination by excreta. All food receptacles shall be kept clean and
shall be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. If self-feeders are used for the feeding of pelleted feed,
measures must be taken to prevent molding, deterioration or caking of the feed. Hamsters may be fed
|pelleted feed on the floor of a primary enclosure.

) (7)

(b) (6), (b) (7)(C)
Date(s): 2016

§ 3.30 - Watering. (REPEAT)

Unless food supplements consumed by guinea pigs or hamsters supply them with their normal water
requirements, potable water shall be provided daily except as might otherwise be required to provide
adequate veterinary care. Open containers used for dispensing water to guinea pigs or hamsters shall be so
placed in or attached to the primary enclosure as to minimize contamination from excreta. All watering
receptacles shall be sanitized when dirty: Provided, however, That such receptacles shall be sanitized at least
once every 2 weeks.

The above is not intended to be an all-inclusive list. Please know that you are responsible for ensuring that
your facility, animals, and property are in compliance with the Animal Welfare regulations.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) created federal regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help
prevent the spread of animal and plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and costly impacts that
are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with an Official Warning for the violation(s) described above. Any
further violation of these federal regulations may result in the assessment of a civil penalty, criminal prosecution, or other sanctions.
If you have any questions concerning this Official Warning or violation(s), please contact the APHIS official listed in this notice.

## Enforcement Actions-AWA and HPA-Aug 2016 to Jan 2017_page_635
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CASE NUMBER
ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH INSPECTION SERVICE (b) (6), (b) (7\(C)
ALLEGED VIOLATOR:

(b) (6), (b) (7(C)

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):

OFFICIAL.WARNING (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: August 28, 2014

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(B) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: (2) The (B)
entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse exhibition,
any horse which is sore.

You entered a horse named “The White Mask” into the 76th Annual
Tennessee Walking Horse National Celebration in Shelbyville, TN where it
was found sore and in violation of the scar rule.

Date of Violation: August 28, 2014

9 C.F.R. § 11.3 Scar rule. The scar rule criteria are as follows: (a) The anterior and
anterior-lateral surfaces of the fore pasterns (extensor surface) must be free of bilateral
granulomas,5 other bilateral pathological evidence of inflammation, and, other bilateral
evidence of abuse indicative of soring including, but not limited to, excessive loss of
hair. (b) The posterior surfaces of the pasterns (flexor surface), including the sulcus or
“pocket” may show bilateral areas of uniformly thickened epithelial tissue if such areas
are free of proliferating granuloma tissue, irritation, moisture, edema, or other evidence
of inflammation.

You entered a horse named (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

where it
was found sore and in violation of the scar rule.

An Equal Opportunity Provider and Employer Reference Number: (5) (6), (6) (7)(C)
Issuance Date: December 7. 2016
Version: Final

ADDRESS (City, State, ZIP Code):

OFFICIAL. WARNING (b) (6), (b) (7)(C)

NOTICE OF ALLEGED VIOLATION

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has evidence that on or about the date(s) listed
below, you or your organization committed the following alleged violation(s) of Federal
laws:

Date of Alleged Violation: July 24, 2015

15 U.S.C. § 1824(2)(D) Unlawful acts. The following conduct is prohibited: “(2) The
(A) showing or exhibiting, in any horse show or horse exhibition, of any horse which is
sore, (B) entering for the purpose of showing or exhibiting in any horse show or horse
exhibition, any horse which 1s sore, (C) selling, auctioning, or offering for sale, in any
horse sale or auction, any horse which is sore, and (D) allowing any activity described in
Clause (A), (B), or (C) respecting a horse which is sore by the owner of such horse.”

(b) (6), (b) (7X) was the owner who allowed the horse, (D) (6), (b) (7)(C)

, Where the horse was found
sore during a post-show inspection.

The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) published federal
regulations to ensure the welfare of animals and help prevent the spread of animal and
plant pests and diseases. Since violations of the regulations can have serious and
costly impacts that are detrimental to the public interest, APHIS is providing you with
an Official Warning for the alleged violation(s) described above. This Official
Warning is not to be construed as a final agency action, or as an adjudicated finding of
a violation. If APHIS obtains evidence of any future violation of these federal
regulations, APHIS may pursue civil penalties, criminal prosecution, or other
sanctions for this alleged violation(s) and for any future violation(s). If you have any
questions concerning this Official Warning or alleged violation(s), please contact the
APHIS official listed in this notice.
